paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: An officer of an entity may commit an offence under subsection (1) or (2) whether or not the entity has been prosecuted for, or found guilty of, an offence under that subsection.

section.name: s162
section.heading: Powers of investigation
section.leadIn: A resolution authority may cause an investigation under section 163 to be carried out by an investigator if it has reasonable cause to believe that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence under this Ordinance may have been committed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a direction given to, or requirement imposed on, a controlled entity under this Ordinance has not been complied with.

section.name: s163
section.heading: Powers of investigator to require production of records or documents or attendance for examination

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a person whom an investigator, carrying out an investigation in any circumstance set out in section 162, has reasonable cause to believe—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to be in possession of a record or document that contains, or is likely to contain, information relevant to any matter under investigation by the investigator; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to be otherwise in possession of information relevant to a matter mentioned in paragraph (a).

subsection.leadIn: An investigator may, in writing, require a person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to produce to the investigator, within the time and at the place specified in the requirement, any record or document specified in the requirement that—

subparagraph.content: is or may be relevant to any matter under investigation; and
is in the person’s possession;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to attend before the investigator at the time and place specified in the requirement, and answer any question relating to any matter under investigation that may be raised by the investigator;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to respond to any written question relating to any matter under investigation that may be raised by the investigator; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to give the investigator all other assistance in connection with the investigation that the person is reasonably able to give.

subsection.content: If a person produces a record or document as required under subsection (2)(a), the investigator may require the person to give an explanation or further particulars in respect of the record or document.

On or before imposing a requirement under subsection (2) or (3), the investigator must ensure that the person is informed or reminded of the limitations imposed by section 165 on the admissibility in evidence of the requirement and of the question and answer or response, or the explanation or further particulars.

If a record or document is not produced as required under subsection (2) for the reason that it is not in the possession of the person, the resolution authority may, by notice in writing given to the person, require the person to verify, within any period that the resolution authority may reasonably require, that fact and reason by statutory declaration.

If a person gives any answer, response, explanation or further particulars as required under subsection (2) or (3), the investigator may, in writing, require the person to verify, within the time specified in the requirement, the answer, response, explanation or further particulars by statutory declaration.

If a person does not give any answer, response, explanation or further particulars as required under subsection (2) or (3) for the reason that the information concerned is not within the person’s knowledge, the investigator may, in writing, require the person to verify, within the time specified in the requirement, that fact and reason by statutory declaration.

subsection.leadIn: An investigator—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make interim reports on an investigation to the resolution authority; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must make interim reports on an investigation to the resolution authority as soon as reasonably practicable after being required by the resolution authority to do so.

subsection.content: An investigator must, as soon as reasonably practicable after completing an investigation, make a final report on the investigation to the resolution authority.

section.name: s164
section.heading: Offences for non-compliance with requirements imposed under section 163

subsection.content: A person commits an offence if the person, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement under section 163(2), (3), (5), (6) or (7).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $200,000 and to imprisonment for one year and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine at level 3 for every day during which the offence continues; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 5 and to imprisonment for 6 months and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine at level 3 for every day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in purported compliance with a requirement under section 163(2), (3), (5), (6) or (7), the person produces any record or document, or gives any answer, response, explanation or further particulars, that is or are false or misleading in a material particular; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person knows that, or is reckless as to whether, the record or document, or the answer, response, explanation or further particulars, is or are false or misleading in a material particular.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (3) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: A person is not excused from complying with a requirement under section 163 only on the ground that to do so might tend to incriminate the person.

section.name: s165
section.heading: Use of incriminating evidence in proceedings

subsection.leadIn: This section applies if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an investigator requires a person to give an answer or response to a question or to give an explanation or further particulars under section 163(2) or (3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the answer or response, or the explanation or further particulars, might tend to incriminate the person; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the person claims, before giving the answer or response or giving the explanation or further particulars, that it might so tend.

subsection.content: Despite any other provision of this Ordinance, the requirement and the question and answer or response, or the explanation or further particulars (as the case requires), are not admissible in evidence against the person in criminal proceedings in a court of law other than those in which the person is charged in respect of the answer or response, or the explanation or further particulars, with an offence under section 164(1) or (3) or under Part V of the Crimes Ordinance (Cap. 200).

A magistrate may issue a warrant if satisfied by information on oath laid by a person mentioned in subsection (2) that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that there is, or is likely to be, on premises specified in the information any record or document that may be required to be produced under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: The person is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an authorized person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an investigator;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person who constitutes, or is a member of, a resolution authority; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an employee of a resolution authority.

subsection.leadIn: A warrant issued by a magistrate under this section authorizes a person specified in it (specified person) and any other person assisting in the execution of the warrant, including any police officer, to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter the premises specified in the warrant, if necessary by force, at any time within the period of 7 days beginning on the date of the warrant; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: search for, seize and remove any record or document that the specified person has reasonable cause to believe may be required to be produced under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: If a specified person has reasonable cause to believe that a person found on the premises is employed, or engaged to provide a service, in connection with a business that is or has been carried on on the premises, the specified person may require that person to produce for examination any record or document—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that is in the possession of that person; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the specified person has reasonable cause to believe may be required to be produced under this Part.

subsection.leadIn: A specified person may, in relation to any record or document required to be produced under subsection (4)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: prohibit any person found on the premises from—

subparagraph.content: removing the record or document from the premises;
erasing anything from, adding anything to or otherwise altering anything in, the record or document; or
otherwise interfering with, or causing or permitting any other person to interfere with, the record or document; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: take any other step that appears to the specified person to be necessary for—

subparagraph.content: preserving the record or document; or
preventing interference with the record or document.

subsection.leadIn: Any record or document removed under a warrant may be retained—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a period, not exceeding 6 months, beginning on the day of its removal; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the record or document is or may be required for the purpose of any criminal proceedings or any proceedings under this Ordinance, for any longer period that is necessary for those proceedings.

subsection.content: If a specified person removes any record or document under a warrant, the specified person must, as soon as reasonably practicable after the removal, issue a receipt for the record or document.
A specified person who enters any premises under a warrant must, if required by any person on the premises, produce the warrant for inspection.

Section 102 of the Criminal Procedure Ordinance (Cap. 221) applies to any property that has under this section come into the possession of a resolution authority, as it applies to property that has come into the possession of the police.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if the person—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with a requirement or prohibition imposed on the person under subsection (4) or (5); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: without reasonable excuse, obstructs a specified person exercising a power conferred by subsection (3), (4) or (5).

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (10) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $2,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine at level 6 for every day during which the offence continues; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine at level 3 for every day during which the offence continues.

section.name: s167
section.heading: Lien claimed on records or documents
section.leadIn: If a person claims a lien on any record or document in the person’s possession that is required to be produced under this Part—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the lien does not affect the requirement to produce the record or document;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no fees are payable for or in respect of the production; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the production does not affect the lien.

section.name: s168
section.heading: Production of information in information systems etc.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies in relation to information or matter contained in a record or document that is recorded—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: otherwise than in a legible form but is capable of being reproduced in a legible form; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in an information system.

subsection.content: Any person who is empowered to require the production of the record or document under this Part is also empowered to require the production of a reproduction of the recording of the information or matter, or the relevant part of the recording, in a legible form or in a form that enables the information or matter to be reproduced in a legible form.

section.name: s169
section.heading: Inspection of records and documents seized etc.

subsection.content: An authorized person or an investigator who has taken possession of a record or document under this Part, including a record or document removed under a warrant under section 166, must permit any other person, who would be entitled to inspect the record or document had the authorized person or the investigator not taken possession of it, to inspect it, and to make copies or otherwise record details of it, at all reasonable times.
A person who gives permission under subsection (1) may impose any reasonable condition, as to security or otherwise, that the person thinks fit.

subsection.leadIn: A person commits an offence if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person is required by an authorized person or an investigator to produce any record or document under this Part; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: with intent to conceal from the authorized person or the investigator facts or matters capable of being disclosed by the record or document, the person—

subparagraph.content: falsifies, conceals, destroys or otherwise disposes of the record or document; or
causes or permits the falsification, concealment, destruction or other disposal of the record or document.

subsection.leadIn: A person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.content: If an investigation is carried out under section 163 in relation to a financial institution, the Financial Secretary may order that all expenses incurred in the investigation must be defrayed by the financial institution.
Expenses mentioned in subsection (1) may be recovered as a civil debt due to the Government in any court of competent jurisdiction.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: authorized statutory body (認可法定團體) means—(a)the Insurance Authority;(b)the Monetary Authority; or(c)the Securities and Futures Commission.

subsection.content: The Financial Secretary may, by notice published in the Gazette, amend subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: A person to whom this subsection applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: must preserve, and aid in preserving, secrecy with regard to any matter that comes to the person’s knowledge—

subparagraph.content: in the course of performing a function under, or carrying into effect, any provision of this Ordinance; or
in the course of assisting another person to perform a function under, or carry into effect, any provision of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not communicate a matter mentioned in paragraph (a) to any person other than the person to whom it relates; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must not suffer or permit any person to have access to any record or document that has come into the possession of the person because of a circumstance mentioned in paragraph (a).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: any person who holds or has held an office, appointment, employment or other role under this Ordinance, including as—

subparagraph.content: a resolution authority;
a section 10 entity;
an independent valuer;
an authorized person; or
an investigator;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a member, employee or agent of, or a consultant or advisor to, a resolution authority;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a member, employee or agent of, or a consultant or advisor to, a section 10 entity; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a member, employee or agent of, or a consultant or advisor to, an independent valuer.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not apply to the disclosure of information—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: as necessary for performing any function under this Ordinance or for carrying any provision of this Ordinance into effect;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by a resolution authority if, in the opinion of the resolution authority, the disclosure is necessary in the interests of promoting and maintaining the stability and effective working of the financial system of Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for seeking advice from, or the giving of advice by, counsel or a solicitor or other professional advisor acting or proposing to act in a professional capacity in connection with a matter arising under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: at the request of the Secretary for Justice, with a view to the institution of, or otherwise for the purpose of, any criminal proceedings or any investigation of a criminal complaint;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: in connection with any other legal proceedings arising out of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: to an appeal tribunal;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: by a resolution authority to the Financial Secretary, the Secretary for Justice or a person who constitutes or is a member of an authorized statutory body if, in the opinion of the resolution authority—

subparagraph.content: the disclosure will enable or assist the recipient of the information to perform the recipient’s functions; and
it is not contrary to the resolution objectives or the orderly resolution of a within scope financial institution that the information should be so disclosed;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.leadIn: by a resolution authority (disclosing authority) to another resolution authority if, in the opinion of the disclosing authority—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: is not inconsistent with the achievement of its objectives under this Ordinance; and

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: will enable or assist the other resolution authority to perform its functions, and achieve its objectives, under this Ordinance; and
the other resolution authority is subject to confidentiality requirements and safeguards that are adequate having regard to the nature and sensitivity of the information;

paragraph.content: by a resolution authority to the Hong Kong Deposit Protection Board established by section 3 of the Deposit Protection Scheme Ordinance (Cap. 581) for enabling or assisting the Board to perform its functions under that Ordinance;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: to any person covered by a prohibition in subsection (1) if the disclosure will enable or assist that person to assist the resolution authority to perform its functions under this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.leadIn: by a resolution authority with the consent of—

subparagraph.content: the person from whom the information was obtained or received; and
if the information does not relate to that person, the person to whom it relates; or

paragraph.content: that has been made available to the public by virtue of being disclosed in any circumstances in which, or for any purpose for which, disclosure is not precluded by this subsection or section 175.

subsection.content: Subsection (3)(k) does not require the resolution authority to disclose in or in relation to any civil proceedings any information that it may disclose, or has disclosed, under that subsection.

subsection.leadIn: Except as may be necessary for a purpose mentioned in subsection (6), a person who, in the course of performing a function under this Ordinance, receives information or any record, report, return or other document is not required—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to divulge that information in any court;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to produce that record, report, return or other document to any court; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: to divulge or communicate to any court any matter or thing that came to the person’s knowledge in the course of performing a function under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The purpose is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a prosecution for an offence;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a winding-up by the Court under section 122 of the Banking Ordinance (Cap. 155), Part VI of the Insurance Ordinance (Cap. 41) or section 212 of the Securities and Futures Ordinance (Cap. 571); (Amended 23 of 2016 s. 236)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an application to the Court for a clawback order; or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an appeal to the Court of Appeal from a determination of the Resolution Compensation Tribunal or Resolvability Review Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: If information is disclosed in any of the circumstances mentioned in subsection (3)(a) to (k), the following persons must not disclose the information, or any part of it, to any other person except with the consent of the resolution authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person to whom the information is disclosed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person obtaining or receiving the information, whether directly or indirectly, from the person mentioned in paragraph (a).

subsection.content: However, subsection (7) does not require the Financial Secretary, as a person to whom that subsection applies, to obtain the consent of the resolution authority before disclosing to any other person any information covered by that subsection if, in the opinion of the Financial Secretary, the disclosure is necessary in the interests of promoting and maintaining the stability and effective working of the financial system of Hong Kong.

A resolution authority, in disclosing any information in any of the circumstances mentioned in subsection (3) or in granting any consent under subsection (7), may impose any condition that it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (1) or (7) or who fails to comply with a condition imposed under subsection (9) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s174
section.heading: Confidentiality on the part of financial institutions etc.

subsection.leadIn: An entity or person to whom this subsection applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: must preserve, and aid in preserving, secrecy with regard to any matter that comes to the knowledge of the entity or person—

subparagraph.content: in the course of performing a function under, or carrying into effect, any provision of this Ordinance; or
in the course of assisting another person to perform a function under, or carry into effect, any provision of this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not communicate a matter mentioned in paragraph (a) to any person other than the person to whom it relates; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must not suffer or permit any person to have access to any record or document that has come into the possession of the entity or person because of a circumstance mentioned in paragraph (a).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an entity that is or has been a within scope financial institution;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an entity that is or has been a group company of an entity mentioned in paragraph (a); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a person who is or has been a member, officer, employee or agent of, or a consultant or advisor to, an entity mentioned in paragraph (a) or (b).

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (1) does not prevent an entity or person to whom that subsection applies from disclosing a matter mentioned in that subsection—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for a purpose permitted by section 173(3) in the case of that entity or person; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: with the consent of the resolution authority of the entity if it is or has been a within scope financial institution or of the within scope financial institution of which the entity is or has been a group company, to a body corporate that is a member of the same group of companies as the entity.

subsection.leadIn: If information is disclosed in reliance on subsection (3), the following persons must not disclose the information, or any part of it, to any other person except with the consent of the resolution authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person to whom the information is disclosed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person obtaining or receiving the information, whether directly or indirectly, from the person mentioned in paragraph (a).

subsection.content: A resolution authority, in granting any consent under subsection (3)(b) or (4), may impose any condition that it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (4) and at the time of disclosure knew or ought reasonably to have known that the information, or the part of it, was previously disclosed to the person in reliance on subsection (3) commits an offence unless the person proves that the person had reasonable grounds to believe that the disclosure by the person was—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: with the consent of the resolution authority;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for seeking advice from, or the giving of advice by, counsel or a solicitor or other professional advisor acting or proposing to act in a professional capacity in connection with a matter arising under this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: of information that was available to the public.

subsection.content: An entity or person that contravenes subsection (1) or fails to comply with a condition imposed under subsection (5) commits an offence.

subsection.leadIn: An entity or person that commits an offence under subsection (6) or (7) is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $1,000,000 and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s175
section.heading: Disclosure of information to authorities in other places

subsection.leadIn: A resolution authority may disclose information to a non-Hong Kong resolution authority if in the opinion of the resolution authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the non-Hong Kong resolution authority is subject to adequate secrecy provisions in the non-Hong Kong jurisdiction; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.content: it is desirable or expedient that information should be so disclosed in the interests of furthering the resolution objectives (in so far as Hong Kong is concerned); or

the disclosure will enable or assist the non-Hong Kong resolution authority to perform its functions and it is not contrary to the interests mentioned in subparagraph (i) that the information should be so disclosed.

subsection.leadIn: If information is disclosed under subsection (1), the following entities must not disclose the information, or any part of it, to any other person except with the consent of the resolution authority—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the non-Hong Kong resolution authority to which the information is disclosed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other person obtaining or receiving the information, whether directly or indirectly, from that non-Hong Kong resolution authority.

subsection.content: A resolution authority, in disclosing any information under subsection (1), may impose any condition that it considers appropriate.

section.name: s176
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: proceeds of resolution (處置收益) means any money payable to the Government as a shareholder of an entity (including a bridge institution, asset management vehicle or TPO company) as a result of, or in connection with, the making of a Part 5 instrument;

public money (公帑) means money in an account that is—(a)public moneys as defined by section 2 of the Public Finance Ordinance (Cap. 2); or(b)any other money under the control of the Government or a public officer;

resolution funding account (處置資金帳户) means the account into, and out of which, any of the following are paid—(a)resolution funds;(b)proceeds of resolution;(c)costs recovered under section 177;(d)any remuneration provided to a resolution authority under section 147(2);(e)any interest or fees received in respect of the use of money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account for a purpose mentioned in section 178(4)(a) or (b);(f)any other money received in respect of a use of money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account, including a repayment of money lent as mentioned in section 178(4)(b);
resolution funds (處置資金) means public money paid into the resolution funding account;
resolution levy (處置徵費) means a levy imposed under section 180;

surplus (餘款), in relation to the resolution funding account, means any money standing to the credit of that account after all resolution funds have been repaid, and interest payable in respect of them has been paid, under section 179.

section.name: s177
section.heading: Recovery of costs following application of stabilization option

subsection.content: This section applies if conditions 1, 2 and 3 are met in the case of a within scope financial institution and, as a result, a stabilization option is applied to it or to a holding company or affiliated operational entity of it.

The resolution authority that applied the stabilization option or the Financial Secretary may charge to the financial institution or, if a stabilization option has been applied to a holding company of the financial institution, to both the financial institution and the holding company, all reasonable costs properly incurred by the resolution authority or the Financial Secretary, as the case requires, in or in connection with a matter mentioned in section 178(1)(a) or (b).

However, the resolution authority or the Financial Secretary must not charge costs under subsection (2) if, or to the extent that, the charging of the costs might, in the opinion of the resolution authority or the Financial Secretary (having consulted the resolution authority), undermine the meeting of the resolution objectives.

Any costs charged to an entity under subsection (2) may be recovered from the entity as a civil debt due to the resolution authority or the Government, as the case requires, in any court of competent jurisdiction.
Any money received in respect of costs charged to an entity under subsection (2) (including under subsection (4)) must be paid into the resolution funding account.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (6), money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account may only be used by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a resolution authority in, or in connection with—

subparagraph.content: preparing for the making of a Part 5 instrument in respect of an entity that, in the opinion of the resolution authority, is likely to be an entity in resolution;
the making of a Part 5 instrument in respect of an entity; or
the resolution of an entity, including payment of any compensation due under Part 6 and any associated costs; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Financial Secretary in, or in connection with, the appointment of an independent valuer to perform functions under Part 6.

subsection.leadIn: Money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account may not be used to meet—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: expenses incurred by a resolution authority in performing functions under, or otherwise carrying out, Division 1 of Part 3 or Part 10; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: general operational expenses incurred by a resolution authority unrelated to a matter mentioned in subsection (1)(a).

subsection.leadIn: Before a resolution authority may use money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account in applying a stabilization option to an entity, it must have regard to the extent to which the entity’s own resources can be utilized, including the extent to which—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: liabilities of the entity can be written off or converted to enable it to absorb losses and re-establish its capital position;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: assets of the entity can be sold; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: private sector funding can be obtained by the entity.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1)(a), the purposes for which money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account may be used by the resolution authority include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing a guarantee or indemnity in respect of the assets or liabilities of an entity in resolution, a group company of an entity in resolution, a bridge institution, an asset management vehicle or a TPO company;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: lending money to an entity in resolution, a group company of an entity in resolution, a bridge institution, an asset management vehicle or a TPO company; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if necessary, providing, or underwriting the provision of, capital to an entity in resolution, a group company of an entity in resolution, a bridge institution, an asset management vehicle or a TPO company.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1)(b), the purposes for which money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account may be used by the Financial Secretary include—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the payment of professional fees and expenses in connection with the appointment of an independent valuer to perform functions under Part 6; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the payment of any fees or other costs properly incurred by the independent valuer in connection with performing those functions.

subsection.leadIn: Any money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account that neither the resolution authority nor the Financial Secretary intends to use for a purpose mentioned in subsection (1) must be used to repay resolution funds and, to that end, must be paid—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: out of the resolution funding account; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: into the account from which resolution funds were paid into the resolution funding account.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (6)(b), if resolution funds were paid into the resolution funding account from more than one account, the money must be paid into those accounts in proportion to the amounts paid from those accounts.

Interest, by reference to prevailing market rates, may be charged to the resolution funding account on the outstanding principal amount of resolution funds until repaid under subsection (6) or section 179.
The use of the resolution funding account is subject to audit in accordance with regulations made under section 185.
Any money standing to the credit of the resolution funding account on completion of the resolution must be used to repay any resolution funds or pay interest charged under section 178(8).

Money used for a purpose mentioned in subsection (1) must be paid into the account out of which the resolution funds, or the resolution funds to which the interest relates, were paid into the resolution funding account and, if resolution funds were paid into the resolution funding account out of more than one account, in proportion to the amounts paid out of those accounts.

A resolution levy may only be imposed to the extent that any resolution funds have not been repaid, or interest payable in respect of them has not been paid, under section 179 on completion of the resolution.
The amount to be recovered by way of a resolution levy must not be greater than the sum of any resolution funds not repaid, and interest not paid, as mentioned in subsection (1).

subsection.leadIn: A resolution levy may be imposed on any of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: all within scope financial institutions within the same sector to which the entity in resolution belongs or belonged;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a class of such within scope financial institutions;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the entity in resolution is a financial market infrastructure—

subparagraph.content: all participants of the financial market infrastructure or a class of such participants;
all participants of other financial market infrastructure that are within scope financial institutions or a class of such participants;
all participants of recognized exchange companies designated under section 6(1)(b) as within scope financial institutions or a class of such participants; or
all clients of participants mentioned in subparagraph (i), (ii) or (iii) or a class of such clients;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: if the entity in resolution is a recognized exchange company—

subparagraph.content: all participants of the recognized exchange company or a class of such participants;
all participants of other recognized exchange companies designated under section 6(1)(b) as within scope financial institutions or a class of such participants;
all participants of financial market infrastructure that are within scope financial institutions or a class of such participants; or
all clients of participants mentioned in subparagraph (i), (ii) or (iii) or a class of such clients.

subsection.content: Any payment of resolution levy received by the Government (including under section 183) must be paid into the account out of which the unrepaid resolution funds, or the unrepaid resolution funds to which the interest relates, were paid into the resolution funding account and, if unrepaid resolution funds were paid into the resolution funding account out of more than one account, in proportion to the amounts paid out of those accounts.
The Financial Secretary may make regulations for or with respect to the imposition of a levy in connection with the resolution of a particular entity.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), regulations made under that subsection may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specify the entities or classes of entities by which the levy is payable;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: make different provision for different classes of entities, or for different entities within a class of entity;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: set out the methodology for the assessment of the amount of levy payable by a particular entity or class of entity including the factors on which the methodology relies such as—

subparagraph.content: the size or quantum of the activities of the entity, or of any group company of the entity, measured on the basis of on and off balance sheet assets and liabilities, transaction volumes or other values;

subparagraph.leadIn: the risks posed by the non-viability of the entity, or of any group company of the entity, to the stability and effective working of the financial system of Hong Kong, based on any factors that the Financial Secretary considers relevant which may include—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: financial condition;

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: market share;

subparagraph.name: C
subparagraph.content: substitutability;

subparagraph.name: D
subparagraph.content: stability and variety of sources of funding;

subparagraph.name: E
subparagraph.content: structural complexity and resolvability; and

subparagraph.name: F
subparagraph.content: interconnectedness within the sector or across sectors; or

the extent to which the entity, or any group company of the entity, has benefitted, or would likely benefit, from the orderly resolution of the entity to which a stabilization option has been applied;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: prescribe the manner and timing of payment in respect of the levy;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: prescribe the circumstances in which, and the period for which, payment of the levy may be deferred; or

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: prescribe any other matter relating to the levy or the obligations of entities, or classes of entities, liable to pay it.

subsection.content: Regulations made under this section may make different provision according to when a financial institution by which a levy is payable became, or ceased to be, a within scope financial institution.

subsection.leadIn: Before making regulations under subsection (1), the Financial Secretary must consult—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each sector likely to be affected by the levy;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: each resolution authority; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the general public.

subsection.content: Regulations made under subsection (1) may not come into operation earlier than one month after the day on which they are published in the Gazette.

The Legislative Council may, on the recommendation of the Financial Secretary, by resolution prescribe the rate of a resolution levy in accordance with the regulations made by the Financial Secretary under section 181.
A resolution made under subsection (1) may not come into operation earlier than one month after the day on which it is published in the Gazette.

section.name: s183
section.heading: Recovery of levy
section.content: Any amount of levy that is due and payable by an entity mentioned in section 180(3) may be recovered from the entity as a civil debt due to the Government in any court of competent jurisdiction.

subsection.content: The Financial Secretary may make regulations with respect to how any surplus is to be distributed.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), regulations made under that subsection may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specify who is entitled to any share of the surplus;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify how the share of any person is to be calculated; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: provide for any dispute relating to the distribution of the surplus to be determined by the Resolution Compensation Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: The Financial Secretary may make regulations—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for or with respect to providing for the auditing of the accounting records and financial statements of any entity in so far as those records or statements relate to payments into or out of the resolution funding account; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for connected purposes.

subsection.leadIn: Regulations made under this section may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: apply generally or be limited in their application by reference to specified exceptions or factors; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: apply differently according to different factors of a specified kind.

subsection.content: Regulations made under this section may prescribe offences in respect of contraventions of the regulations, and may provide for the imposition of a fine not exceeding level 6, or imprisonment for a period not exceeding one year, or both, in respect of any such offence.
Regulations made under this section may not come into operation earlier than one month after the day on which they are published in the Gazette.

section.name: s186
section.heading: Interpretation
section.leadIn: In this Part—
section.def: Hong Kong creditor (香港債權人) means a person whose rights under the law of Hong Kong as a creditor of an entity in relation to which a non-Hong Kong resolution action has been taken are, or may be, affected by the making of a recognition instrument;

Hong Kong shareholder (香港股東) means a person whose rights under the law of Hong Kong as a shareholder of an entity in relation to which a non-Hong Kong resolution action has been taken are, or may be, affected by the making of a recognition instrument.

section.name: s187
section.heading: Recognition of non-Hong Kong resolution actions

subsection.content: This section applies if a resolution authority is notified of the taking of a non-Hong Kong resolution action.

The resolution authority may make a recognition instrument, irrespective of whether the non-Hong Kong financial institution or non-Hong Kong group company to which the instrument relates is a within scope financial institution.

subsection.leadIn: A recognition instrument is an instrument that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: recognizes the action; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recognizes part of the action but does not recognize the remainder.

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after making a recognition instrument, the resolution authority must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: send a copy of the instrument to the non-Hong Kong financial institution or non-Hong Kong group company to which the instrument relates;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: publish a copy of the instrument on its internet website; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: cause notice of the making of the instrument to be published—

subparagraph.content: in the Gazette; and

in 2 newspapers (one being an English language newspaper and the other being a Chinese language newspaper) chosen by the resolution authority to maximize the likelihood of the notice coming to the attention of persons likely to be affected.

subsection.content: A resolution authority may only make a recognition instrument after having first consulted the Financial Secretary.

subsection.leadIn: A resolution authority must not make a recognition instrument if the resolution authority is of the opinion that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: recognition would have an adverse effect on financial stability in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recognition would not deliver outcomes that are consistent with the resolution objectives; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: recognition would disadvantage Hong Kong creditors or Hong Kong shareholders (or both) relative to other creditors or shareholders of the entity in relation to which the non-Hong Kong resolution action has been taken.

subsection.content: In deciding whether to make a recognition instrument, a resolution authority may take into account any fiscal implications for Hong Kong of the making of the instrument.
A recognition instrument takes effect at the time, or on the date, specified in it.
Subject to section 193, the making of a recognition instrument has no effect on the taking of any step for the winding up of an entity affected by the non-Hong Kong resolution action.

section.name: s188
section.heading: Effect of recognition of non-Hong Kong resolution actions

subsection.content: This section applies if a resolution authority makes a recognition instrument.

The non-Hong Kong resolution action (or the part of it) that is recognized by the recognition instrument produces substantially the same legal effect in Hong Kong that it would have produced had it been made, and been authorized to be made, under the laws of Hong Kong.
Section 25 does not apply to the making of a recognition instrument.
A resolution authority must not make a recognition instrument unless it is satisfied that an arrangement that meets the criteria mentioned in subsection (2) is in place.

Any Hong Kong creditor or Hong Kong shareholder is eligible to claim compensation under an arrangement with the non-Hong Kong resolution authority that took the non-Hong Kong resolution action (or the part of it) that is to be recognized by the recognition instrument that is broadly consistent with the eligibility provided by section 102.
A recognition instrument may include incidental, consequential or transitional provisions.

subsection.leadIn: In relying on subsection (1), a recognition instrument—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may make provision generally or only for specified purposes, cases or circumstances; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may make different provision for different purposes, cases or circumstances.

subsection.content: This section applies if a resolution authority is notified of the taking of a non-Hong Kong resolution action.

The resolution authority may for the purpose of supporting the non-Hong Kong resolution action exercise, in accordance with this Ordinance, any power that it has under this Ordinance if of the opinion that doing so would be consistent with the resolution objectives.

section.name: s192
section.heading: Notice of intention to present winding up petition to resolution authority

subsection.leadIn: A petition for the winding up by the Court of a within scope financial institution or a holding company of a within scope financial institution may not be presented to the Court unless—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the petitioner—

subparagraph.content: has given notice in writing of the intention to present the petition to the relevant resolution authority or, if the financial institution or holding company is within a cross-sectoral group, the lead resolution authority of the group; and
has caused a copy of the draft petition to be attached to the notice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: either—

subparagraph.content: the period of 7 days, beginning on the day on which the notice is received, has ended without the relevant resolution authority or lead resolution authority initiating the resolution of the financial institution or holding company; or

the relevant resolution authority or lead resolution authority has informed the petitioner within that period of 7 days that it does not intend to initiate the resolution of the financial institution or holding company; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the following period has not ended—

subparagraph.content: in the case of paragraph (b)(ii), the period of 14 days beginning on the day on which the petitioner is informed under that paragraph.

subsection.content: A petition presented to the Court in contravention of subsection (1) is void from the beginning.
The Chief Justice may make rules regulating the practice and procedure of the Court for giving effect to subsection (1).

section.name: s193
section.heading: Restriction on commencement of winding up proceedings

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a within scope financial institution or a holding company of a within scope financial institution—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: to which the stabilization option mentioned in section 33(2)(d) (bail-in) has been applied but either a bail-in provision contained in a bail-in instrument under section 58(2), or a provision made under section 61(1) or 64(3)(a), has not yet been fully implemented; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: to which a non-Hong Kong resolution action, recognized by a recognition instrument, broadly comparable to action mentioned in paragraph (a) has been initiated and is ongoing.

subsection.content: Despite any provision in any other Ordinance, winding up proceedings may not be commenced in relation to the financial institution or holding company except with the consent in writing of the resolution authority.

section.name: s194
section.heading: Disapplication of certain provisions
section.leadIn: Despite anything to the contrary in the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6), the Companies Ordinance (Cap. 622) or the Companies (Winding Up and Miscellaneous Provisions) Ordinance (Cap. 32)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Part 5 instrument, a capital reduction instrument or a recognition instrument must not be set aside, annulled or avoided under any of those Ordinances; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order must not be made by a court under any of those Ordinances for the rectification of any such instrument or for a stay on its operation.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, without reasonable excuse, obstructs a specified person in the performance of a function under, or in carrying into effect, any provision of this Ordinance commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment to a fine of $2,000,000 and to imprisonment for 5 years and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine at level 6 for every day during which the offence continues; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 2 years and, in the case of a continuing offence, to a further fine at level 3 for every day during which the offence continues.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: specified person (指明人士) means—(a)a resolution authority;(b)a section 10 entity;(c)a member, employee or agent of a resolution authority;(d)an independent valuer; or(e)any person in relation to the taking by the person of any action in compliance with, or in giving effect to, a direction of a resolution authority under this Ordinance.

subsection.content: A resolution authority may issue a code of practice about any matter relating to the functions given to it by this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: The code may, in particular—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: provide guidance on—

subparagraph.content: the approach to, and procedures for, resolution planning and resolvability assessment (including the removal of impediments to orderly resolution);
how the resolution authority proposes to determine whether condition 1, 2 or 3 is met;
the procedure to be followed in connection with the making of any capital reduction instrument;
the selection of stabilization options;
the procedure to be followed in connection with the application of any stabilization option;
the determination of compensation under Division 3 of Part 6, including assumptions to be made, principles to be applied and processes to be followed in making a valuation; or
how the resolution authority proposes to exercise its powers compatibly with the safeguard provided for by regulations made under section 75(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: provide guidance in relation to the governance, management and control of a bridge institution, asset management vehicle or TPO company, including guidance in relation to—

subparagraph.content: the setting of objectives;
the content of the articles of association;
the content of reports required under this Ordinance; and
eventual disposal.

subsection.content: The code may also, in relation to the functions given to the resolution authority by this Ordinance, provide guidance on the operation of any provision of this Ordinance.

A code of practice issued by a resolution authority under subsection (1) may incorporate or refer to a code of practice, or any part of a code of practice, from time to time issued by another resolution authority under that subsection.
This section applies if a provision of this Ordinance that creates an offence makes a reference to a reasonable excuse for a contravention to which the provision relates.
The reference to a reasonable excuse is to be construed as providing for a defence to a charge in respect of the contravention to which the provision relates.

subsection.leadIn: A defendant is to be taken to have established that the defendant had a reasonable excuse for the contravention if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sufficient evidence is adduced to raise an issue that the defendant had such a reasonable excuse; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the contrary is not proved by the prosecution beyond reasonable doubt.

section.name: s198
section.heading: Prosecution of offences by resolution authority

subsection.content: A resolution authority may prosecute an offence under this Ordinance, or an offence of conspiracy to commit such an offence, in its own name.
Any offence prosecuted under subsection (1) must be tried before a magistrate as an offence that is triable summarily.

subsection.leadIn: For prosecuting an offence mentioned in subsection (1), any person to whom this subsection applies, even if he or she is not qualified to practise as counsel or to act as a solicitor under the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may appear and plead before a magistrate in any case of which the person has charge; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has, in relation to the prosecution, all the other rights of a person qualified to practise as counsel or to act as a solicitor under that Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Subsection (3) applies to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the Monetary Authority, a person appointed under section 5A(3) of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Cap. 66); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any case, an employee of the resolution authority.

subsection.content: This section does not derogate from the powers of the Secretary for Justice in respect of the prosecution of criminal offences.

A person is not civilly liable for an act done or omitted to be done by the person in good faith in performing or purportedly performing, or assisting a person in the performance or purported performance of, a function under this Ordinance, including a function delegated to the person.
Subsection (1) does not apply to an appeal tribunal or the chairperson or an ordinary member of an appeal tribunal.
Subject to subsection (2), this Ordinance does not affect any claims, rights or entitlements that would, apart from this Ordinance, arise on the ground of legal professional privilege.

Subsection (1) does not affect any requirement made under this Ordinance to disclose the name and address of a client of a legal practitioner (whether or not the legal practitioner is qualified in Hong Kong to practise as counsel or to act as a solicitor).

section.name: s201
section.heading: Certain instruments are not subsidiary legislation
section.leadIn: The following instruments are not subsidiary legislation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a notice under section 6(1)(a) or (b) or (4);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a notice under section 7;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a Part 5 instrument;

paragraph.name: d

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a recognition instrument;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: a code of practice issued under section 196(1).

section.name: s202
section.heading: Power of resolution authorities to specify forms

subsection.content: A resolution authority may specify the form of any document required for the purposes of this Ordinance.
Subsection (1) does not apply to a document the form of which is prescribed by regulations or prescribed by rules made by the Chief Justice.

subsection.leadIn: The Financial Secretary may make regulations that amend Schedule 1 by—

paragraph.name: a

subsection.content: The Financial Secretary may make regulations that amend Schedule 5 by adding to the list of excluded liabilities.
